document.masterDocTitle: Revision of the South African endemic bee genus Redivivoides Michener, 1981 (Hymenoptera: Apoidea: Melittidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Revision of the South African endemic bee genus Redivivoides Michener, 1981 (Hymenoptera: Apoidea: Melittidae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Females and males of
R. variabilis
can be separated from other
Redivivoides
species by their black to brown metasomal terga which are smooth and shiny between punctures and that lack white apical hair bands ( Figs 15 E-F, 16E). This is the only
Redivivoides
species where terga have an intense oily bluish shine.
The species is named after the colour variation of the females.
Type material ( 31 specimens )

materialsCitation.collectorName: K. Steiner & Host Plant & N. C. Prov.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 15.
Redivivoides variabilis
sp. nov. , ♀. A . Lateral view (light form). B . Lateral view (black form). C . Head. D . Scutum and scutellum. E . Metasoma (dorsal view) (light form). F . Metasoma (dorsal view) (black form). Scale bar: 1 mm.

Fig. 16.
Redivivoides variabilis
sp. nov. , ♂. A . Lateral view. B . Scutum and scutellum. C . Metasoma (dorsal view). D . S6 (ventral view). E. S7 (dorsal view). F . S8, apical end (backscattered electron image). G . Genitalia (dorsal view). H . Genitalia (lateral view). Scale bar: 1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: BODY LENGTH. 12.0-13.0 mm.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 17. Distribution of
Redivivoides variabilis
sp. nov. in South Africa.

subSubSection.paragraph: WINGS. Yellowish-brown; wing venation brown.

METASOMA. Integument black, except apical tergal margins partly narrowly brownish translucent; terga with intense oily bluish shine ( Fig. 15 E-F). T1 apically sparsely covered with a few long erect yellowish hairs; T2 – T4 covered with short yellowish-white hairs; apical tergal hair band missing on T1, on T2 – T4 very sparse and only laterally developed ( Fig. 15 A-E). In the dark form all hairs black, no apical tergal hair bands ( Fig. 15 B-F). Prepygidial fimbria dorsally black, laterally partly yellowish white (in dark form all black), pygidial fimbria black. Terga densely but finely punctate, smooth and shiny between punctures ( Fig. 15 E-F).
BODY LENGTH. 12.0-13.0 mm.

HEAD. Head slightly wider than long. Integument black except tip of mandible partly dark reddish-brown. Face densely covered with long, whitish-grey to yellowish-brown, erect hairs intermixed with black hairs along the inner eye margins and on vertex. Malar area medially narrow, almost linear. Antenna black, ventrally dark reddish-brown.
WINGS. Yellowish-brown; wing venation brown.
LEGS. Integument black, tibiae and tarsi partly yellowish-brown. Vestiture yellowish-white.

The species has been found in most parts of Namaqualand to the northern parts of the Roggeveld Mountains in the southeast ( Fig. 17 ). The colour form with females all black is only known from the higher grounds of the south-eastern part of the species' range while the females with light brown pilosity mostly occur in lower areas and the north ( Fig. 17 ). Colour variation is also known from
Rediviva gigas Whitehead & Steiner, 1993
and
R. parva Whitehead & Steiner, 2001
. In
R. gigas
there is no obvious geographical pattern of colour variation but the black form of
R. parva
seems to be concentrated in the north and in lower lying areas in the west of its range ( Whitehead & Steiner 2001 ).
